importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu delivered his address at Mount Herzl cemetery, reaffirming that the struggle against Hamas is not over, and marking the anniversary of Hamas’ October 7, 2023, attack.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period following the ceasefire agreement in early October 2025, during which the dispute over the return of deceased hostages has intensified, and diplomatic efforts to locate remains and ensure compliance with the deal are ongoing.

keyTakeAways: Israel and Hamas agreed to a ceasefire in early October 2025, with Hamas releasing 20 living hostages and Israel releasing over 1,700 Palestinian detainees and 250 prisoners.

Hamas has released only the remains of nine of the 28 deceased Israeli hostages, sparking outrage in Israel and raising concerns that Hamas may have hidden the locations of at least six additional bodies.
Israel believes Hamas has access to at least six bodies and possibly more, with intelligence indicating that five bodies have 'disappeared' and others are disputed.
A mechanism for searching for missing bodies was agreed upon but has not yet begun operating, despite US and international efforts to provide logistical and intelligence support.
The United States does not believe Hamas is violating the agreement, citing assurances from third-party mediators, but continues to support efforts to locate remains.
Turkey has proposed sending body-retrieval specialists with earthquake recovery expertise to assist in locating remains in rubble.
The Hostages and Missing Families Forum has criticized the ceasefire as incomplete and demanded that Hamas return all hostages and fulfill its obligations.
Israel initially threatened to restrict humanitarian aid to Gaza in an attempt to pressure Hamas, but has since backed down, allowing aid to flow under ceasefire terms.
More than 700 aid trucks entered Gaza on Wednesday, exceeding the 600-truck daily cap in the agreement, primarily via the Kerem Shalom crossing.
The UN has warned that humanitarian aid should not be used as a bargaining tool, emphasizing its legal obligation to provide aid to Gaza.
Israel still occupies about 50% of Gaza, and the ceasefire remains contingent on Hamas disarming, which has not been resolved.
Netanyahu has not declared the war over and reiterated that the 'struggle is not over,' vowing to 'achieve all the goals of this war' and bring back all hostages.
US President Donald Trump has indicated he would consider allowing Israel to resume military action if Hamas fails to uphold its end of the ceasefire.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Netanyahu is the central political figure asserting that the conflict with Hamas is not over, and he publicly reaffirmed Israel’s commitment to recovering all hostages and defeating Hamas, which is central to the article’s narrative of unresolved conflict and national resolve.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is the primary adversary in the conflict and the subject of ongoing disputes over the return of deceased hostages and the release of prisoners, making it the key actor in the ceasefire breakdown and the core of the conflict described.

namedEntities.name: Hamas al-Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The al-Qassam Brigades have publicly stated their adherence to the ceasefire agreement and claimed they have returned all living captives and accessible bodies, directly contributing to the dispute over missing remains.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US brokered the ceasefire deal and now plays a key role in mediating the dispute over missing bodies, offering support and assurances to both sides, and acting as a stabilizing force in the region.

namedEntities.name: Turkey
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Turkey has offered to send body-retrieval specialists with earthquake recovery expertise to assist in locating buried remains, showing international diplomatic involvement in the humanitarian recovery effort.

namedEntities.name: United Nations
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The UN expressed concern over Israel’s threat to restrict humanitarian aid, emphasizing that aid delivery is a legal obligation and not a bargaining tool, reinforcing the ethical and humanitarian dimensions of the conflict.

namedEntities.name: Mount Herzl Cemetery
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This is the site where Netanyahu delivered a speech commemorating fallen soldiers and marking the anniversary of Hamas’ October 7 attack, symbolizing the emotional and historical gravity of the conflict.

namedEntities.name: COGAT (Coordinator of Government Activities in the Territories)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: COGAT provides official data on the flow of humanitarian aid into Gaza, which is critical to understanding the implementation and enforcement of the ceasefire agreement.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump has indicated he would consider allowing Israel to resume military action if Hamas fails to return all hostages, showing the potential for US policy shifts in the conflict.

namedEntities.name: Hostages and Missing Families Forum
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This group is pushing for Hamas to fulfill its obligations under the ceasefire, demanding that all hostages be returned and calling the current status a moral and leadership failure.

namedEntities.name: Kerem Shalom
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The primary entry point for aid trucks into Gaza, with over 700 trucks passing through on one day, indicating high volumes of humanitarian movement despite ceasefire constraints.

namedEntities.name: Kissufim
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A secondary crossing with fewer than 100 aid trucks passing through, highlighting uneven distribution of humanitarian access within Gaza.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Following a ceasefire agreement brokered by the United States, Egypt, Qatar, and Turkey, Israel and Hamas have made significant progress in releasing hostages and detainees. However, a major dispute persists over the return of the bodies of 28 deceased Israeli hostages, with Hamas releasing only nine remains and Israel alleging that Hamas holds at least six more. Despite US assurances that Hamas is fulfilling its commitments, Israel believes it has access to hidden bodies and is pushing for a full search mechanism. International actors including Turkey and the United Nations are involved in efforts to locate remains and prevent humanitarian aid from being used as a bargaining tool. Meanwhile, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu reaffirms that the 'struggle is not over,' vowing to bring back all hostages and maintain military pressure, while the ceasefire remains incomplete due to unresolved issues over Hamas disarming and Israeli withdrawal from Gaza.
title: Netanyahu says ‘struggle is not over’ as dispute with Hamas over hostage bodies continues
